title: Report: Texas expected to settle with former AD Steve Patterson for $2.8 million
text:
Recently ousted Texas athletic director Steve Patterson is reportedly will receive a contract settlement totaling $2.8 million, according to a report by HornsDigest.com.
The Texas board of regents are expected to approve the settlement Thursday, two unnamed sources told HornsDigest, a little more than one week after Patterson and the university split after a number of controversial decisions by the AD.
When Patterson was brought on board in November 2013, he received a five-year deal worth $1.4 million per year, according to past responses to open-records requests by The Dallas Morning News.
Patterson will receive $1.4 million in each of the next two years, according to the report. Texas, however, won't have to pay Patterson next year if he finds a new job that will pay him at least $1.4 million. The university would need to make up the difference if Patterson's new job paid less than $1.4 million, the website reported.
New Texas President Greg Fenves announced the decision on a conference call Sept. 15 in what he called a resignation after a "mutually-agreed upon decision." The school had used similar terminology to describe the firings of football coach Mack Brown and men's basketball coach Rick Barnes.
Fenves said it wasn't one or two particular concerns that led to this decision.
"This has been a decision that has been building over recent weeks, not a very long time," Fenves said. "And I felt the risks of not accepting his resignation at this time and try to have him stay outweighed the benefits."
Patterson's predecessor, DeLoss Dodds, spent 32 years in Austin building the most financially successful athletic department in the country. Patterson lasted 22 months.
